critique: The document aims to convey joy and surprise through the increase in cash allowance for members of the Conservation Corps. The tone is formal and authoritative, reflecting the President's role. The language is straightforward and focuses on the practical aspects of the allowance. The context is the Great Depression, where unemployment was high, and the government was trying to provide relief. The primary emotions the President wants to elicit are joy and surprise, as the increase in cash allowance would improve the lives of the members of the Conservation Corps. There might be a slight element of reduced sadness as well. There is no indication of anger, fear, or disgust.
